metadata.title: Glucose Sensing by Fluorescent Nanomaterials
authors: Joaquim C. G. Esteves da Silva

sections.text: KEYWORDS Diabetes mellitus; fluorescence; glucose sensors; nanomaterials; optical sensing

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Glucose is the major energy source in cellular metabolism and has a vital role in the natural growth of cells. Glucose blood level is usually used as a clinical indicator of diabetes. Diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease that occurs when the pancreas does not produce enough insulin or when the body cannot effectively use the insulin it produces. The chronic hyperglycemia, or high blood glucose levels, of diabetes is associated with long-term damage, dysfunction, and failure of different organs, predominantly the kidneys, nerves, heart, and blood vessels.[1] In its most severe forms, this medical condition can cause ketoacidosis which, in turn, can lead to stupor, coma and without expeditious treatment, death.[2] Generally, glucose serum concentrations in healthy and diabetic individuals range from 3 to 8mM and 2 to 40mM, respectively.[3] Thus, the rapid and accurate quantification of glucose in human blood is essential in the diagnosis and management of the disease.
The most investigated technology for glucose sensing is based on electrochemistry with almost every available glucose monitoring device on the market making use of amperometric sensors to quantify glucose concentration.[4–7] However, there are disadvantages to the utilization of electrochemical biosensors, which include invasiveness, intermittent measurements, accuracy, lifetime and signal reduction
from fouling agents.[8,9] Therefore, there is an increasing demand for new technologies in the blood sugar monitoring market that can fill the gap and eliminate electrochemical biosensors limitations.[10]
Reviews focusing on fluorescence biosensing have been published since the beginning of the twenty-first century, with nanomaterials taking the center stage in more recent years. Fluorescence glucose sensing by single molecules like concanavalin A, glucose oxidase and dehydrogenase, bacterial glucose-binding proteins and boronic acid derivatives has been reviewed, first by Pickup et al. in 2005,[11] and in a review that focused more on boronic acids by Xiaolong Sun and Tony D. James in 2015.[12] Other authors have focused on the use of different nanomaterials in fluorescence general sensing.[13,14] Here, we offer a review that focus on glucose sensing by fluorescent nanomaterials, with an emphasis both on their sensing/luminescence mechanisms and on corresponding analytical performances.
Fluorescence technology has progressively evolving in the last decade and represents a promising alternative to electrochemistry for the analysis of glucose in diabetes patients.[4] Fluorescent optical sensors use light in variable frequencies to detect glucose, due to the interaction of the fluorophores with glucose in a concentration-dependent manner.[15] Fluorescence has high sensitivity and easy measurement and

represents an exceptional strategy for glucose detection. A variety of fluorescence approaches to glucose sensing have been developed based on intensity and lifetime measurements, which present advantages like sensitivity and the potential for non-invasive measurement when near infrared light is used. Fluorescence strategies can be extremely sensitive and cause little to no damage to the host system. Usually, the proposed fluorescence sensors are based in different fluorescence sensing strategies: quenching; enhancement; turn off-on; turn on-off, ratiometric; anisotropy (FA); resonance energy transfer (FRET); photoinduced electron transfer (PET); and, metal enhanced fluorescence (MEF).
Fluorescence-based sensors offer several advantages in comparison to the more outdated electrochemical-based systems. These include: extreme sensitivity with very low limits of detection[10]; virtually no damage done to the host organism due to high penetration depth into tissues of the NIR light that allows the measurement of glucose concentration without any invasive procedure[11]; the possibility of measuring fluorescence not only by its intensity but also by its lifetime[16]; and, immunity from electrical interference.
Nanomaterials are characterized mainly by two properties: the size (any material between 1–100 nm in size); and, the size-dependent properties of a given material.[17] The nanomaterials are one of the most promising materials for the development of in vivo sensors owing to their particular physical and chemical properties.[9,13,18,19] In this review, the following nanomaterials will be reviewed: carbon dots (CD), quantum dots (QD), upconversion nanoparticles (UCNP), graphene quantum dots (GQD) and silver (AgNP) and gold (AuNP) nanoparticles.
This review focuses on the nanomaterials fluorescence sensing mechanisms for glucose sensing and is divided into two main parts. The first focuses on indirect fluorescence strategies, by sensing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) resulting from the coupling of the enzyme glucose oxidase (GOx) with a nanomaterial, enabling the quantification of glucose by sensing H2O2. The second contains direct glucose fluorescence strategies, in which said sensors make use of nonenzymatic receptors to detect glucose. The main characteristics of the nanomaterials applied in the fluorescent glucose sensors analyzed in this review are also presented.
Herein, methods of hydrogen peroxide sensing, and direct glucose sensing, using nanomaterials were presented because the determination of these compounds is of upmost importance in the control of various diseases in particular the diabetes. This review is focused on glucose sensing by fluorescent nanomaterials, with an emphasis both on their sensing/luminescence mechanisms and on corresponding analytical performances. A large variety of approaches could be applied to enhance the sensitivity and the selectivity of the nanomaterials fluorescence methods. Thus, it were presented fluorescence glucose sensors based in nanomaterials developed in the last years. A substantial amount of the fluorescent sensors presented is based on indirect strategies, more specifically, based in the reaction between glucose and GOx. However, enzymatic assays are generally expensive, complex and time-consuming and the results provided by
these methods are affected by changes in temperature and oxygen concentration. There are few methods based in metallic nanoparticles (AuNPs and AgNPs). The majority of the glucose sensors were based in QDs and for an indirect detection of glucose. The majority of the direct nanosensors use boronic acid motifs as a receptor for glucose.

sections.text: There are glucose sensors based in nanoparticles (NP) sensible to H2O2 that, when coupled to the enzyme that will produce it, for example GOx, or other emulating systems, will respond indirectly to glucose. sections.heading: Carbon dots
sections.text:
Carbon dots (CD) are sp3 hybridized carbon nanoparticles with spherical shape that range from 1–10nm.[20] These nanomaterials exhibit tunable and non-blinking photoluminescence, photostability, biocompatibility, low photobleaching and low toxicity.[21] A variety of “bottom-up” and “top-down” synthesis methods of CDs from a selected carbon precursors and doping molecules are well documented in the literature.[22] Moreover, surface functionalization is a pathway for developing tailor made features by introducing functionalities to the surface of the nanoparticle (e.g., addition of carbonyl or hydroxyl groups) such as providing specific binding motifs for target analytes.[22]
Reduced graphene oxide decorated with CD (CD@RGO) was used in the detection of H2O2 and glucose, based on H2O2-induced fluorescence enhancement.
[23] CD@RGO were hydrothermally prepared from catechin and graphene oxide. The suggested sensing mechanism was based on the reaction of H2O2 and reactive oxygen species (ROS) present in the nanocomposite surface that quenches radiative emission. Better sensitivity was observed in the presence of 10mM BSA in the concentration ranging from 1 to 60mM (r¼ 0.99) and with a LOD (S/N¼ 3) of 140 nM. The concentrations of glucose were measured in serum and saliva samples[23].
Wei et al. showed that the fluorescence of CD prepared from gelatin is linearly quenched by H2O2 in the presence of Fe(II).[24] The presence of Fe(II) and H2O2 results in the formation of the hydroxyl radical through Fenton reaction, which will provoke quenching of the fluorescence. Thus, this system can detect glucose in the presence of GOx. The fluorescence of these CD was quenched linearly by H2O2 over the concentration range 0.025–50 lM. In addition, a linear correlation was established between the quenching and the concentration of glucose in the range from 0.05 to 100lM.[24] CD prepared from hydroquinone and doped with boron using BBr3 using a one-pot solvothermal route, showed fluorescence quenching in the presence of H2O2 and were used as a sensor for glucose in the presence of GOx (Figure 1).[25] The sensor exhibited a linear response to glucose concentration from 8.0 to 80.0mM with a LOD of 8.0 lM.[25]
A turn-on fluorescence strategy, schematically shown in Figure 1, is based on the quenching of the CD fluorescence by another NP, following by a fluorescence recovering that result from the reaction of H2O2 with that NP (Figure 2). AgNP[26] and MnO2 nanosheets
[27] were used as NP to quench the CD fluorescence and GOx was used to oxidize glucose for H2O2 production and consequent fluorescence recovering. These methods allow the detection of glucose in blood serum in the 2 to 4000 lM concentration range with a LOD of 1.39 lM,[26] and up to 125 lM with a LOD of 44 nM.[27]

sections.heading: Quantum dots
sections.text:
Quantum dots (QD) are fluorescent semiconductor NP characterized by high quantum yields and quantum confinement, having narrow emission bands, large absorption spectra, large stokes shift, fluorescence tunable size, high surface to volume ratio and photostability. QD have found numerous applications in sensing and biosensing but, due to its high market cost and their inherent high toxicity, their
potential applications have reduced and slowed down the industrial production.[28]
Kim et al. reported a glucose biosensor using CdSe/ZnS mercaptoacetic acid (MAA) QDs and GOx, showing a fluorescence intensity enhancement. Electron transfer resulting from glucose oxidation to the QDs led to the enhancement of the photoluminescence (PL) intensity by spontaneous electron-hole recombination. The use of MAA not only provided water solubility to the QDs, but also aided in the efficient electron transfer. The increase in the PL intensity is proportional to the concentration of glucose in the solution, achieving a linear increase in the range of 0 to 15mM.[29]
Gill et al. developed a ratiometric fluorescent nanosensor capable of detecting glucose by having their fluorescence quenched by H2O2. [30] The coupling of GOx with

Other sensors that relied on this same quenching mechanism by H2O2 include systems containing GOx and L-mercaptosuccinic acid (MSA)-CdSe/ZnS QD,[31] nanocomposite films of immobilized CdTe QD and GOx,[32] glutathione (GSH)-capped CdTe QD,[33] mercaptopropionic acid (MPA)-capped CdTe/CdS QD,[34] bioanalytical platform based on GOx and CdTe QD,[35] immobilized GOx and CdTe/thioglycolic acid (TGA) QD on a thin-layer chromatography (TLC),[36] and paper spots loaded with colloidal CdSe/ZnS QD and GOx.[37] All of these methods, with the exception of the last one, allow the detection of linear responses to glucose, in buffer or in blood serum, in concentrations ranging from 1 mM to 30mM with LODs starting at 12.5 nM[36] and up to 1.8 mM.[34] The paper-based assay showed a sigmoidal-shaped response with respect to the glucose concentration in the 5 to 200mg dL 1 range with a LOD of 5 lg dL 1.[37]
A different quenching method, schematically shown in Figure 2, was developed by Wang et al. who assembled a TGA-capped CdS QD–bienzyme (GOx and horseradish peroxidase (HRP)) hybrid system to detect glucose, using o-phenylenediamine (OPD) and 3,30-diaminobenzidine (DAB) as the substrate of HRP.[38] In this method, the oxidation of glucose to gluconic acid catalyzed by GOx resulted in the production of H2O2. The subsequent formation of the oxidized product 2,3-diaminophenazine (DAP), resulting from the oxidation of OPD in the presence of HRP and H2O2, led to quenching of the fluorescence intensity of the TGA-capped CdS QDs. When DAB is used as the substrate, oxidation by H2O2 leads to the formation of a brown macromolecular product (oxDAB). The fluorescence quenching of the CdS QDs was proportional to the concentration of glucose and presumably due to photo-induced electron transfer (PET) between the DAP and the QDs (Figure 3(a)). Another possible theory is that DAB oxidation polymerization and the inner filter effect (IFE) of oxDAB induces the aggregation of the TGA-capped CdS QDs (Figure 3(b)). Two linear responses ranging from 0.5mM to 1.0mM and 1.0mM to 10mM were obtained, with and LOD of 0.1mM.

sections.heading: Graphene quantum dots
sections.text:
GQD represent single-layer to tens of layers of graphene and is another example of zero-dimensional carbon nanostructures. GQD consist of disk-shaped graphene particles with sp2-sp2 carbon bonds with sizes most commonly ranging from 2–30 nm.[39] Due to its exceptional properties such as low toxicity, stable photoluminescence, chemical stability and pronounced quantum confinement effect, GQD are used in biological, opto-electronics, energy and environmental applications. Doping GQD with heteroatoms can effectively tune their intrinsic properties, including optical characteristics and surface and local chemical features. Therefore, they have been widely used in imaging, optical and electrochemical sensing, diagnosis and therapy.
Hemin-functionalized GQD was used for glucose detection, based on H2O2-assisted fluorescence quenching. [40] When adsorbed on the GQD’s surface, hemin would slightly decrease their fluorescence intensity as a result of the modification to the nanoparticle’s surface. Addition of H2O2 would further increase fluorescence quenching probably due to the destruction of the surface passivation of the GQDs. Coupling the proposed biosensor with GOx as molecular recognition element, made it possible to extend the sensing system to glucose detection. A linear response was observed in the range of 9 to 300mM with a LOD 0.1 mM. Following similar H2O2-induced fluorescence quenching strategies, Zhang et al. developed a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)/GQDs nanofibrous membrane via a technique of electrospinning,[41] whereas Li et al. assembled tyramine (TYR)-functionalized GQDs[42] for glucose detection. These methods allow for the detection of glucose in PBS solutions in the 0.25 to 24mM concentration range with LODs of 10 mM[41] and 7.2 nM[42], respectively. Zhang et al. developed a turn-on fluorescence strategy by combining GQDs with Fe(III) 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(1-methyl4-pyridyl)porphine (FeTMPyP).[43] In this case, quenching of fluorescence by the FeTMPyP is observed due to inner filter effect (IFE). The presence of H2O2 switches back “on” the luminescence of the GQDs, in response to the reaction between FeTMPyP and H2O2, which causes the decrease of absorbance because of the breakdown of FeTMPyP to colorless dipyrroles and monopyrroles. This “turn on” sensing system can be extended to the detection of glucose in combination with the specific catalytic effect of GOx. The calibration curve for glucose detection shows a linear response from 3 to 100mM (R2¼ 0.992) with a LOD of 0.5 mM.

sections.heading: Silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have generally sizes around 1 nm and 100 nm and have been studied because of their unique properties that allow their application in the field of medicine and therapeutics.[44] More specifically, AgNPs have been applied in sensing and imaging applications, allowing
different detection methods with low detection limit like colorimetric, scattering, SERS, and MEF.
A method for glucose fluorescence sensing applying AgNP was based in a fluorescence turn-on strategy for detection via the AgNP mediated release of a perylene probe.[45] It was observed that the fluorescence of a perylene probe could be quenched by the AgNPs. The perylene probe could be attached to the surface of the AgNP due to strong electrostatic attractive and hydrophobic interactions resulting in the quenching of fluorescence of perylene. The AgNPs are etched by H2O2 generated from the enzymatic oxidation of glucose releasing the perylene probe. So the perylene probe could not be quenched and is able to emit fluorescence (a turn-on fluorescence signal is detected) which could be used for the quantification of glucose. The fluorescence emission intensity increased with increasing concentrations of glucose (0 to 200mM).

sections.heading: Upconversion nanoparticles
sections.text:
Upconversion nanoparticles (UCNP) can be defined as lanthanide-doped NP that are capable of exhibiting photon upconversion (UC), a fluorescent luminescence process.[46] Lanthanides are most usually found in their ionized trivalent state, after having lost their 5d and 6 s electrons. The trivalent lanthanides are doped in an inorganic dielectric host lattice composed by other lanthanides, actinides or transition metals (Yttrium and Scandium). Rare-earth ions have the capability of transforming low-frequency near-infrared (NIR) radiation into high-frequency UV/Vis. radiation. This process leads to an anti-Stokes type of emission, denominated “upconversion emission”. The host lattice is a transparent crystalline structure that accommodates the dopants by determining its spatial distribution and coordination numbers. Good host materials need to have specific characteristics, which include low phonon energies to avoid efficiency losses through non-radiative transfer, high optical transparency, good crystallinity and chemical stability.[47] As for the dopants, lanthanide trivalent ions have been the primary choice when synthetizing UCNP as their energy levels are the most suitable for the promotion of the upconversion process by the absorption of multiple photons. The lanthanide dopants work in pairs as one serves as the sensitizer (Yb3þ) and the other functions as the activator (e.g., Er3þ, Tm3þ, Ho3þ).[48]
Unlike most of the other fluorescent nanoparticles already mentioned, which are used in sensors that use quenching by H2O2 as the main sensing mechanism for glucose, UCNP rely almost exclusively on turn-on strategies for their sensors. Liu et al. reported a turn-on nanosystem, schematically shown in Figure 3, based on polydopamine (PDA)-UCNP for the detection of glucose in alkaline solutions, as well as in human serum and whole blood samples.[49] The lanthanide ions on the surface of ligand-free UCNP possess great affinity toward the dopamine monomers (DA), allowing them to spontaneously attach to them, either by electrostatic attraction or strong chelation of the lanthanides, and polymerize DA. The creation of this PDA
shell around the UCNP surface led to an UC quenching of 97.4%. In the presence of H2O2, the DA polymerization was prevented; therefore, inhibiting the quenching effect caused by the high absorbance of the PDA shell in the visible region and restoring the UCL. The UC intensity of the UCNP/DA/GOx/glucose system increased linearly with glucose concentration from 0–300mM, and a LOD of 0.8 mM was determined with selectivity and specificity. Furthermore, the applicability of this nanosystem was determined by carrying out glucose detection tests in human serum and whole blood, which are possible due to the negligible interference from autofluorescence of biological samples and scattering light under the excitation of NIR light. A linear response was observed for the serum samples on glucose concentration ranging from 0–250mM, with an LOD of 1.2 mM. Finally, the coefficient of variation (CV) of all assays were below 8.6% and the recoveries were in the range of 95.2%–107.4% confirming the accuracy and precision of this methodology.
A similar method was used by Yuan et al.[50] and Wu et al.[51]. The former developed manganese dioxide (MnO2) nanosheets modified UCNP, with the nanosheets working as the quencher of fluorescence.[50] The upconversion fluorescence intensity in phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) was linearly related to the glucose concentration in the range of 0–250 mM (R2¼ 0.990) and 250–400mM (R2¼ 0.985), respectively. LOD was estimated to be 3.7 mM. The developed method was applied to three human serum samples and two whole blood samples with recoveries ranging from 96.0%–104.5% and a relative standard deviation (RSD) of around 5%. Wu’s et al. created a luminescence resonance energy transfer (LRET)-based UC hybrid nanocomposite for glucose sensing, composed of DNA-templated Ag nanoparticles (DNA-AgNP) and UCNPs.[51] The DNA-AgNP would act as quenchers of the UCNP luminescence and H2O2 would restore it by etching the AgNP into Agþ and inhibiting the LRET process, causing the recovery of the UC. In aqueous buffer solutions, linear relationship was found for glucose concentrations ranging from 2.5–100mM, with a LOD of 1.41 mM. Human serum tests also generated positive results, achieving a linear response for glucose concentrations between 2.5–100mM, with a LOD of 2.65 mM. Recoveries ranged from 101.5% to 104% and a RSD around 4% was obtained.Although UCNP-based sensors display extreme sensitivity for glucose and with all the benefits that come from using NIR light, they still are only capable of obtaining responses for a limited range of concentration. This is one critical aspect that they have to improve in order to be considered as viable options for the development of glucose sensors.

sections.heading: Direct glucose sensing
sections.text:
Glucose fluorescence detection can be made directly by modification of the photophysical properties of a NP. In this case, NP are prepared or its surface modified by known non-enzymatic carbohydrate receptors such as boronic acid derivatives and lectins like concanavalin A (Con A). ConA
is a carbohydrate-binding protein, or lectin, which is able to bind itself to specific structures found in different sugars, glycoproteins and glycolypids. ConA-glucose biosensors are based on the premise that increasing glucose concentrations will inhibit the binding between the lectin and a competing ligand, which are usually fluorochrome-labeled dextrans (FTIC-dextran), causing changes in the fluorescence intensity.[52] Boronic acids have been used in the continuous search for the ultimate fluorescence glucose sensor. The interest in these receptors is based on the ability of alkylarylboronic acids to reversibly bind diols. The reversible covalent interaction with 1,2-, 1,3-, or 1,4-diols transforms boronic acids into 5-, 6-, or 7-membered cyclic esters. The interaction of a boronic acid (Lewis acid) and neighboring tertiary amine (Lewis base) enables the recognition of saccharides, such as glucose, via PET fluorescence quenching. Both these molecular receptors have been extensively reviewed as fluorescence glucose sensors by Pickup et al. in 2005 [11] and in 2015 by Xiaolong Sun and Tony D. James in 2015.[12] Table 2 describes the main characteristics of the direct glucose sensing based on fluorescent nanomaterials sensors.

sections.heading: Carbon dots
sections.text:
Shen et al. published one of the foremost and most cited articles regarding direct sensing of glucose by functionalized CDs,[53] which methodology is schematically shown in Figure 4. They describe a novel one-step fabrication strategy to produce fluorescent CDs sensible to glucose. These CDs were prepared via hydrothermal carbonization using phenylboronic acid (PBA) as the sole precursor. As mentioned before, the addition of glucose leads to the assembly of the CDs due to covalent binding between the cis-diols of glucose and the boronic acid moieties on the CDs’ surface, which ultimately causes the quenching of their fluorescence. In this particular case, a linear response was observed as function of glucose concentration (solutions prepared in PBS buffer solutions at pH ¼ 7.4), ranging from 9–900mM with an LOD of 1.5 mM. Additionally, the selectivity of this CD was assessed by studying their response to potential
interfering substances, including amino acids, ascorbic acid, glutathione and uric acid. These substances had very little effects on the CD’s fluorescence. While this CD is highly sensitive to glucose, its reduced linear range (below 1mM) presents a critical disadvantage for sensors aimed at diabetic people.
Other sensors, that rely on this type of quenching mechanism, are being proposed based on other phenylboronic acids, including 3-aminophenyl boronic acid (APBA)CD,[54] 3-HPBA functionalized nitrogen-doped carbon dots (NCDs) (APBA-NCDs)[55] and poly(5-indolylboronic acid)imprinted-CDs.[56] These sensors displayed improved linear ranges from 0 to 100mM, although only the one sensor achieved a LOD of 5 mM and demonstrated a potential applicability in real samples of human serum, obtaining recoveries from 92.7% to 107.5% of the different known amounts of added glucose.
A turn-on sensor consisting of citric acid based CDs with 4-cyanophenylboronic acid (CPBA) was developed by Krishna et al.[57] The methodology relies on the quenching of the fluorescence emission of the CDs by CPBA, which would be followed by its recovery due to the addition of increasing amounts of glucose. A linear relationship was found within the range of 1–30mM, and interferences by
other saccharides and other relevant biomolecules were considered negligible.
Wang et al. demonstrated a different approach by immobilizing glucose CDs into a glucose-imprinted poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-acrylamide-vinylphenylboronic acid) [poly(NIPAMAAm-VPBA)] copolymer microgels, schematically shown in Figure 5.[58] These microgels respond to the variation of surrounding glucose concentration by reversibly swelling or shrinking, which is then corresponded to the quenching and recovery of the fluorescence signals of the CDs, therefore converting biochemical signals into fluorescent ones. The highly imprinted hybrid microgels showed high sensitivity for glucose detection over a range of 0–30mM at physiological pH. Unlike most these studies, the toxicity of the hybrid nanostructure was evaluated by conducting cell viability tests, which showed marginal cytotoxicity in the concentration range of 25–100mg/mL. This same group went on to publish another paper a year later using upconversion CDs embedded in the same hybrid mentioned above, that not only can detect glucose but it is also able to regulate insulin delivery.[59] Using the same swelling and shrinking mechanism, but with the addition of utilizing NIR light to avoid fluorescence background originated from biomolecules and increase the signal-to-noise ratio, this sensor showed linear correlation to the increase in glucose concentration in the range of 0–20mM at biological pH.

sections.heading: Quantum dots
sections.text:
A turn-on nanobiosensor based on fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) between concanavalin A (ConA)conjugated CdTe QDs and thiolated b-cyclodextrins (b-SHCDs)-modified gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) was designed for the direct determination of glucose in serum.[60] This sensing approach uses CdTe QDs as an energy donor in close proximity to the AuNPs, which acts as the energy acceptor, therefore quenching de QDs’ fluorescence. Upon addition of glucose into the system, it competes it the AuNPs- b-CDs for the binding sites of ConA located on the surface of the
QDs, displacing the AuNPs segment of the nanobiosensor and ultimately leading to fluorescence recovery maximum of 90%. Experimental results show a proportional increase in fluorescence intensity for glucose concentration ranging from 0.10–50mM, which is a relatively small range for biological glucose detection, with a low LOD of 50 nM. Furthermore, the selectivity of this nanobiosensor was also evaluated by testing the effect of other sugars and biological species, which demonstrated to have little to no influence on glucose determination, with a relative error within the range of ±5.0%. This sensor allows recoveries between 97–104% and an RSD below 2.5%.
Wang et al. also designed CdTe QDs labeled with ConA (ConA-CdTe QDs) for glucose detection, but the addition of glucose led to the quenching of the fluorescence of the QDs.[61] Using glutathione (GSH) as a stabilizer and glutaraldehyde as a coupling agent, successful conjugation between the ConA and the QDs was achieved. Results showed that fluorescence intensity decreased linearly (R2 ¼ 0.0995) for glucose concentrations within the range of 0.04–0.2mM with a LOD of 0.01mM. In addition to its restricted detection range, this sensor also displayed lack of selectivity since adding other carbohydrates in the same concentration to the QDs-ConA solution, also caused (although in a less pronounced way) the decrease of fluorescence intensity. Using this same strategy of quenching the QDs’ fluorescence by adding glucose to the system was followed by Wu et al. [62] and Tang et al.[63] Wu et al. developed a glucose detection sensor based on the in situ immobilization of CdS QDs in the interior of boronic acid-based microgels.[62] The fluorescence of CdS QDs in the copolymer microgels of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-acrylamidephenylboronic acid) [p(NIPAM-AAm-PBA)] changes when the microgel undergoes swelling and deswelling in response to glucose concentration. The luminescence intensity of the QDs almost linearly decrease with glucose concentration ranging from 0–13.5mM, with higher concentrations of glucose causing a decreasing of the quenching rate due to maximum stretch of the microgel’s network chains.

Tang et al. designed a metal-enhanced fluorescence (MEF) system for direct determination of glucose.[63] Conjugating mercaptoglycerol-modified AgNPs with APBAfunctionalized CdSe QDs through the formation of boronate ester bonds led to a 9-fold fluorescence enhancement of the QDs’ fluorescence. The fluorescence of the AgNP-CdSe QD system is quenched by the addition of glucose through the competitive binding of glucose to the boronic acid ligands. The decrease in fluorescence has a linear relationship with glucose concentration (in PBS solutions at pH 7.4) in the range between 2 to 52mM, with a LOD of 1.86mM. This system may present promising applications in chemical and biological sensors due to its extensive detection range.

sections.heading: Graphene quantum dots
sections.text:
Qu’s et al. synthesized 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid (APBA) functionalized graphene QDs (APBA-GQD) and used them as a selective and sensitive sensing system for glucose.[64] The APBA groups on the GQD’s surface act as glucose receptors, which is an efficient quencher of the fluorescence of this system. Upon glucose binding, an elastic tension is introduced by the competing repulsive and atractive forces on APBA-GQD’s interface, thereby creating surface states for efficient fluorescent quenching. This system presents a linear response to glucose concentration in aqueous solutions over a range from 0.1–10mM with a LOD of 5.0 mM, as well as showing great selectivity for glucose since other saccharides did not provoke significant fluorescence intensity changes.
Using GQD with a boronic acid substituted bipyridinium salt (BBV), a label-free turn-on fluorescence sensor for glucose detection was proposed.[65] The pristine GQD act as fluorescent reporting unit and BBV serves as a fluorescence quencher. This occurs by the formation of a ground-state complex which facilitates the excited-state electron transfer
from the GQDs to BBV, which in turn leads to the quenching of the fluorescence of the GQDs. The addition of glucose to the system leads to the conversion of the boronic acids into their tetrahedral anionic glucoboronate esters, which neutralize the net charge of the cationic bipyridinium, thus decreasing its quenching efficiency and restoring the fluorescence intensity of the GQDs. A linear relationship between the recovered FL intensity of GQD and the glucose concentration from 1 to 60mM was observed.
Zhang et al. reported a hydrothermal approach for the cutting of boron-doped graphene (BG) into BGQDs for glucose sensing, schematically shown in Figure 6.[66] The generation of boronic acid groups on the BGQDs surfaces facilitates their application as a photoluminescence (PL) probe for label-free glucose sensing. It is suggested that the reaction of the two cis-diol units in glucose with the two boronic acid groups on the BGQD surfaces creates structurally rigid BGQD glucose aggregates, restricting the intramolecular rotations and thus resulting in a great enhancement in the PL intensity. This sensing process excludes any saccharide with only one cis-diol unit, as manifested by the high specificity of BGQD for glucose over its close isomeric forms fructose, galactose, and mannose. When glucose is added to the BGQDs solution in pH 7.4 phosphate buffer, the fluorescence intensity of the BGQD linearly increases with the glucose concentration in the range of 0.1 to 10mM with a LOD of 0.03mM.

sections.heading: Silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Water-soluble fluorescent silver nanoclusters anchored with APBA (AgNC-a-APBA) were synthesized sonochemically.[67] Glucose provokes the quenching of the fluorescence and it is possible detect it in a linear range of 0.5 to 10mM with a LOD of 0.1mM. Sensing of glucose was done by fluorescence quenching. Namely, the fluorescence decreased with
increase in concentration of glucose. The observed quenching was an indication of molecular level interaction (breaking of H-bonding of AgNCs-a-APBA by glucose molecule) in addition to normal collisional quenching.
The method was used to assess glucose levels in human blood samples.

sections.heading: Gold nanoparticles
sections.text: AuNP present unique optical properties, easy surface modifications and good biocompatibility. AuNP also display plasmon absorption bands that depend on their size and shape[68]. A ratiometric fluorescent probe for sensing glucose applying AuNP was developed using gold nanoclusters protected by ovalbumin, with the role of reference of fluorophore, and the Alizarin Red S-APBA immobilized on the poly(N-acryloxysuccinimide) that acted as both the response signal and specific recognition unit for sensing glucose.[69] When the probe reacted with glucose its fluorescence at 567 nm was quenched, while the fluorescence intensity at 610 nm was almost unaffected.

sections.heading: Upconversion nanoparticles
sections.text: Zhang et al. developed a glucose biosensing platform based on FRET from UCNP (NaYF4: Yb, Er), which works as the energy donor, to graphene oxide (GO), the energy acceptor.[70] In this case, the ConA and chitosan (CS) were covalently attached to the UCNP and GO, respectively, to obtain a tight binding between them that would bring into proximity the UCNP and GO, therefore inducing the energy transfer. Energy transfer from UCNP to GO was investigated by measuring the fluorescence quenching. An overall degree of quenching of 81% was obtained with a GO concentration of 0.22mg mL 1. This hybrid biosensing platform showed good linear relationship between donor fluorescence intensity and increasing glucose concentrations from 0.56 to 2.0 mM, with a LOD of 0.0025 mM. The specificity of this FRET sensor toward glucose was also assayed in control experiments with other biomolecules such as carbohydrates, proteins and amino acids. At a concentration of 2.4 mM, none of the tested substances caused obvious restoration of fluorescence, with the exception of mannose.

sections.heading: Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text:
Fluorescence-based glucose sensors have proven to be a viable and worthy alternative to the mainstream electrochemical sensors used worldwide. Fluorescence sensing is a technique that have as advantages the rapidly, facility of application, is non-invasive and require a small volume of reagent per analysis. Their major point is the fact that they are minimally invasive compared to the already existing glucose sensors.
Nanomaterials can be applied in glucose fluorescence sensing. Diverse approaches could be applied to enhance the sensitive and selective fluorescence detection. In this revision, an extensive review on the recent advances on
fluorescence glucose optical sensors with nanomaterial in their constitution, their individual characteristics and analytical performance toward the ultimate glucose biosensor. The application of the presented nanomaterials in the development of optical fluorescent sensors for the glucose sensing was presented. This article also serves as a chronological guideline for the numerous achievements that have been made in this research field over the last 40 years. Nonetheless, there are still hurdles that need to be overcome. A significant amount of the described fluorescent sensors is based on indirect strategies, more specifically, they respond to stimulus provided by the reaction between glucose and GOx. However, the dependence on this enzymatic reaction is not recommended. Enzymatic assays are expensive, generally complex and time-consuming. Moreover, the results provided by these methods are affected by changes in temperature and oxygen concentration. These methods have also limited shelf-life and present difficult sterilization. The majority of the glucose sensors were based in QDs and for an indirect detection of glucose. There are a few number of methods based in metallic nanoparticles (AuNPs and AgNPs). Thus, fluorescent assays based on the direct interaction between glucose and the sensor should be more advantageous. However, typical fluorescent nanosensors strongly absorb UV or visible light, which is unsuitable for biological applications due to problems regarding light absorption and scattering. To overcome these problems, the development of upconversion nanosensors appears to be highly desirable, as these nanoparticles can be photo-excited by infrared radiation, which is appropriated for biological and biomedical applications. Nevertheless, upconversion nanoparticles have no intrinsic affinity for glucose and are not easily modifiable. Therefore, the development of glucose recognition strategies for these nanoparticles is an extraordinarily complex problem. Finally, most of the nanosensors involved in direct approaches use boronic acid motifs as a receptor for glucose. However, boronic acids are not specific for glucose but recognize to different degrees several diol molecules (such as other sugars). Furthermore, it is not clear what the mechanism that controls the selectivity of boronic acids towards specific diols is, which strains the application of these molecules as specific glucose receptors. In conclusion, the resolution of these issues will most likely change the glucose sensors and diabetes market for the foreseeable future.

metadata.abstractText: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease and leading cause of death worldwide, affecting more than 420 million people. High blood glucose levels are a common effect of uncontrolled diabetes, which can cause serious health damage. Diabetic individuals must measure their blood glucose levels regularly in order to control glycemic levels and minimize the effects of the disease. Glucose sensors have been used in the management of diabetes for more than 50 years, when Clark and Ann Lyons developed the first glucose enzyme electrode in 1962. Electrochemical sensors have become the leading technology for glucose concentration measuring with most of the commercially available devices being based on amperometric detection. However, the detection of glucose in the blood is still an object of intense research. The development of new fluorescent nanomaterials begins to constitute an alternative for glucose blood quantification. These sensors include carbon dots, quantum dots, graphene quantum dots, gold, silver and upconversion nanoparticles. This paper reviews the last 10 year fluorescent nanoparticles based technologies proposed for glucose monitoring and provide an insight into emerging optical fluorescence glucose biosensors.
